title: Reactive Machines and Limited Memory AI
content:
Module 2, Lesson 2: Reactive Machines and Limited Memory AI

Introduction

Arend Hintze's classification framework distinguishes AI by memory and self-awareness. Understanding these categories clarifies what today's AI can and cannot do.

Key Concepts

1. Reactive machines (stateless AI)

Understanding Reactive machines (stateless AI) is foundational to this topic. Indian companies and research institutions apply these principles in production AI systems every day.

2. Limited memory AI

Limited memory AI forms the core methodology for practitioners. India's tech ecosystem from Bengaluru to Hyderabad deploys these approaches at scale.

3. How ML models use training-time memory

How ML models use training-time memory is critical for building reliable AI solutions. Top Indian firms like TCS, Wipro, Infosys, and startups like Razorpay all leverage these techniques.

4. Real-time limited memory in Indian apps

Mastering Real-time limited memory in Indian apps separates good practitioners from great ones. Apply these concepts on Indian open datasets from data.gov.in to build hands-on expertise.

Summary

This lesson covered Reactive machines (stateless AI), Limited memory AI, How ML models use training-time memory, and Real-time limited memory in Indian apps. These are the building blocks of reactive machines and limited memory ai — master them through practice on real Indian datasets.

quiz.question: What distinguishes Reactive Machine AI from Limited Memory AI?
options: Reactive machines have no memory of past interactions

quiz.question: Which famous chess computer is a classic Reactive Machine?
How does Ola surge pricing use Limited Memory AI?
options: It memorises all historical trip data
It reacts to last-hour demand patterns

quiz.question: Where is memory "stored" in a trained ML model?
What is Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) used for?
options: Providing selective memory by fetching relevant stored context
